newsitem.title: UK: GOLF-WEBB CHALKS UP RECORD WIN AT BRITISH OPEN.
newsitem.headline: GOLF-WEBB CHALKS UP RECORD WIN AT BRITISH OPEN.

text.p: Australian Karrie Webb won the women's British Open for the second time in three years with a record-breaking total at Sunningdale on Sunday.

The 22-year-old Queenslander, who led by eight shots after a record third round 63, posted a final round 71 to set a British Open record of 19 under par 269 - five better than the previous best set by American Jane Geddes at Ferndown in 1989.
American Rosie Jones birdied the 18th to match Webb's 71 and snatched second place from Sweden's Annika Sorenstam.
After taking the 82,500 pounds ($132,000) winner's cheque, and regaining the trophy she won at Woburn two years ago, Webb said: "I am over the moon to win the British Open again.
"I have been wondering when everything was going to come together and it was this week. I played brilliantly."

Webb, who won over a million dollars and topped the LPGA Order of Merit in her rookie season in the U.S. last year, stuttered in the early stages when she dropped three shots - she had only made two bogeys in the first three rounds - in an outward half of two over par 38. At that stage, the gap had narrowed to five over Jones, her playing partner.
But as the rain started to pour down, she birdied the 299-yard par four 11th from four feet, and back-to-back birdies at the 14th and 15th put her on easy street.

"I was a little bit concerned when the lead went down to five. But I learned from losing the Australian Masters (she led by five going into the final round) that I had to concentrate on my game," she said.
